summary:
Title: What If? Peter Parker Became The Punisher #1
Summary: I downloaded this comic on the Marvel app because it sold out at my...
body:
Title: What If? Peter Parker Became The Punisher #1

Summary: I downloaded this comic on the Marvel app because it sold out at my local comic store and was very expensive on eBay. I was a bit disappointed with this story to be honest. I thought that it must be something special because it was sold out everywhere. For a “What If?” it wasn’t hugely different to Peter’s real origin. Not awful, but could have been much better.

Rating: 5/10

reblog.comment:

summary:
Title: Spider-Man Life Story: #1 The 60’s
Summary: I wasn’t able to get the normal cover without spending at least £15 on eBay,...
body:
Title: Spider-Man Life Story: #1 The 60’s

Summary: I wasn’t able to get the normal cover without spending at least £15 on eBay, this variant cover was normal prices so it’s what I got. This was a lot better than I was expecting! I thought it would be a simple retelling of Spidey’s origin- in fact it was a rework of his origin! It perfectly captures that Spider-Man spirit but sets up a whole new world.

Rating: 9/10

blog.name: dmydfilmreviews
blog.title: dMYDfilmreviews

d = don't
 M = maybe

title: IRON MAN
body:
You just couldn’t do them, not really. A lot of Marvel’s dominance of the box-office is that it was simply time: digital code warping itself to the point that it could look like your childhood dreams, or the images that flashed behind your eyes when you flipped through the pages that Stan and Jack wrote. But you still couldn’t do it, not quite, not in 2008, so you needed something else. The year’s other ‘comic’ spectacular still revelled in the grounded thrills of flipping trucks and ta-daing pencils into gangster’s eyes, and their heroes still had to be rooted in a least some kind of nebulous ‘reality’; the audience still wasn’t ready for Incredible Hulks suplexing giant Asgardian wolves off the wrong side of a rainbow bridge, and the computers couldn’t quite make it happen yet anyway. Marvel would eventually make these things fly on screen the way they always had on the page, but they couldn’t do it yet. So they just needed a good movie, for people who didn’t care about superheroes, people they could convince to go with them to a bunch of magic gems being gnawed by a space raccoon. They got one.

 They got one by gambling. They hired a washed-up drug fuck, starting his climb back up Hollywood hill. Iron Man made Robert Downey Jr. the biggest movie star in the world, and it was mainly down to the guy’s own willpower; he’s astoundingly good in this film, effortlessly cool and loveable, the template for every cocky jerk with a heart that the studio would return to time and again from Thor to Captain Marvel. It’s a star performance from the old days, the kind everyone says is dead now, even though the MCU’s casting is one of its essential elements. Downey’s Jr’s scenes, and he’s basically the whole movie, bring delightfully light improv to a genre previously wrapped in all kinds of seriousness, whether he’s screwball-romancing an equally effortless Gywneth Paltrow, gritting his way through defining character-building in the Afghanistan caves or tete-a-tete-ing with the first of his endless parade of bald nemeses in the form of Jeff ‘BUNCH A SCRAPS’ Bridges. He nails the character’s central pull of asshole-to-protector, a drive that would flesh out in fascinating ways over the next ten years, by simply acting the shit out of it, while around him everyone else also has an indie-movie performance ball, leading a whole host of humanity to something that’s pretty lacking in the action areas the genre craves: the final clash is basically a quick smack on a motorway, while there’s an oh-so-2000s scene of Pepper oh-so-excruicatingly COPYING SOME FILES that wouldn’t be seen dead in the MCU nowadays outside of Taika Waititi making Thor organize a Led Zep playlist or whatever in Thor 5.

It’s a good film, and in its set-up for an unthinkable cinematic universe it’s a great one. By rolling the dice in a number of ways Marvel hit it out of the park from the beginning, focusing on character and tone over spectacle, bolstered by design work and an effects department that were just starting to flex some impressive muscles. It did it’s job, creating a winning voice that said ‘hey, what’s up, we’re here to have some fun.’ It’s a shame no one told the guys on the other lot.
